I'll start this by saying that I really do like the game and its concept. The mechanics, while frustrating at times, feel like they have a certain fun in their novelty, and I do enjoy all of the various adjusting and full control that they've tried to implemment in this game. Based on these factors alone, I would be tempted to give this game a positive review; all that being said, I do not give this game a strong recommendation however much I would like to. The positive attributes that D.U.S.T. holds are currently overshadowed by the lack of player-base, the oversimplistic map design, and the general disorganization of layout.

It becomes very apparent that the game lacks a large enough playerbase to produce exciting matches when the only server containing more than 0-1 players is comprised of 90% bots. This point alone would not generally turn me off to the game; I play many games regularly such as Insurgency, Star Wars Batllefront II, CS:GO, etc. which benefit greatly from the inclusion of bots and remain entertaining when playing matches even entirely comprised of NPCs/AI. But the nature of the bots in D.U.S.T. are simply frustrating. After spending so much time setting myself up (filling my canteen, adjusting sights, slowly travelling across the colossal empty plains, etc.), it is severely enraging to find that I am immediately acquired and killed by a bot from 75+ meters away with god-like accuracy. I understand that this game is intended for a hardcore, simulation audience, but when the average player, or even perhaps an operator in the real world, takes much more effort in the way of aim and could expend an entire magazine before being able accurately hit their target at medium-long ranges, it is severely enraging to find myself targetted and dropped by a bot after immediate, inhuman adjustmentsand  only 2-3 rounds sent my way. This simple gripe would be forgivable in its own right, perhaps it would even be an endearing quality. D.U.S.T. is, after all, intended to be a very hardcore, unforgiving simulation game, however a problem arises when this effect is combined with my other two component gripes with this game: scope of map design and organization of its layout.

The design of the map in this game is ambitious, something which I generally admire about this project as a whole. Its 4km x 4km in size, a titantic playing area for a first person shooter, especially one without an established publisher's support. This is something I would generally have considered a positive trait, and something which actually drew me in primarily; but it is also fundamentally flawed considering the overall developmental state the game is currently in, a point which I will further explain after establishing my dependent complaint in the map's organization. The general layout of this map, disregarding its size, is quite good actually. There is a central city, positioned in a bowl" of surrounding hills; American and Russian "control points" are tangent to the North and South of the city respectively and factional deployment areas are located within 50-100m of these points. Early Access Review

Pros:
Mechanic wise the game feels good, but rough.
Sound effects are well made.
Lots of in-depth weapon customization planned.
Friendly community.
Graphics are fine and so is the performance.


Cons:
Game is very bare and there isn't much content.
Sound distance is messed up in 0.2.0.0 and it's not very enjoyable.
Steep learning curve if you have no idea of what you're doing.
Bugs, bugs everywhere!(Early-Access*cough*)
No vehicles(yet), alot of running ahead of you.

Conclusion:
As of the early-access release patch I wouldn't recommend anyone to buy it if they're looking for a GAME to play, however you like the concept of the game and want to take part in TESTING and help finding bugs then this is definitely for you, plus you may also have something to say when it comes to new mechanics and items.


Great game if you enjoy games like Arma, Squad & DayZ, but want the realism turned up a tad more.
While the game isn't clunky when you already know all the keybinds and trust me, there's alot of them that you have to remember, it certainly is trial and error for the first few hours,

However, this is an early-access title afterall and you have to consider that if you're considering of buying it. Right now, if you just press random buttons you'll eventually end up being stuck on whatever weapon/item you're currently carrying and have to rejoin the server to fix it.
Almost every item in the game as of 0.2.0.0 can potentially bug your animation and lock it completely.

Why am I recommending the game when it is clearly broken?
I have personally been looking for a title like this for a very long time and this is just a bare core-concept of what the game is going to be like when Terapoly starts to update it.
Some people may like all the complicated things that you have to do, some may not. Once you get the hang of it, it's not really that complicated.
Most of the keybinds are placed in such a way that it makes sense when you know what you're doing, therefor making the learning curve very steep if you have zero knowledge of how a gun work but once you know those things it just makes sense in some way.

While I'm only 20'ish hours into the game I've already experience multiple adrenaline rushes.
That one second when you're about to engage in a firefight with someone and everything is in slow-motion, you have to know how and what to do with your gun and I guess that is what makes it so satisfying.
YOU ACTUALLY HAVE TO THINK WHILE PLAYING.

In the current state the game isn't about just killing and shooting everyone you see; It's EARLY-ACCES after all.
Yes, you can join a server, figure out how to shoot and have fun for a couple of hours, but that's about it, so if you plan on buying it to PLAY it and not TEST it then I'd advise you to look elsewhere until Terapoly pushes out some updates to make the game more stable, because if you try to play it just to play it, you'll  end up quitting before you learn how to shoot your gun because of all the frustrating bugs.

As everyone else said please take a tour around Terapoly's forums to better ready yourself before you enter the battlefield of D.U.S.T.
Review posted on early-access release version 0.2.0.0 - I'll update it as we get updates for the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DISCLAIMER: This game IS Early Access, as in VERY early access. There ARE many bugs, weird issues, and wonky UI to work around. There ARE often teamkillers in spawn and the first outpost, and there are not that many people playing at the moment.

That out of the way, this game looks really promising. For several reasons:

1. The concept is REALLY cool! And what's here right now matches the concept pretty well. You need to load a round into the chamber (left shift), take the safty off (down arrow), and then pull the trigger (in a much more interesting way than normal: press and scroll back on the middle mouse button). And that's just the gun. You also need to use a water bottle to stay hydrated in the desert, move your head to be in line with the sights, and you will most likely die on the second (if not the first) shot that hits you.

2. The community (aside from the teamkillers) is pretty helpful. Everyone's new to the game, but people who understand the controls will often respond to questions posed in the chat on what to do to get playing. And there's a lot of questions asked in chat...

3. (side note) The teamkillers (in my experience) generally just hang around the team spawn, and sometimes the first outpost. All I've had to do to generally avoid them is to sprint away as soon as I spawn, fill up my canteen, and head for one of the three middle bases to start capping the flags.

4. The map is HUGE! I've still never made it to the enemy spawn, because it's at least a 5-10 minute sprint away. That walled tower everyone sees when they spawn is just the first outpost. If you go over the hill behind it, you'll see a huge valley with three unique bases, each of which has a flag to cap. (And yes, the flags work, they just take a REALLY long time to come down).

5. The devs have been decently transparent about what's been happening, and have stated they plan to release some patches very soon (like within the week, as of 10/21/15)

So, conclusion? If you're willing to take the effort to learn how to work with your equipment, and work around the bugs in a very early access game, then go ahead! Pick up a copy and try it! The devs have only been working on this for about 6 months, as a 2 person team, so the state the game is in right now is actually pretty impressive.

If you aren't willing to deal with issues that an Early Access game is bound to have (not going to go on a rant...), don't buy it. Yet. Definitly look into buying it at some point. But don't give it a bad review quite yet, when you've already been warned by this and other reviews.


Two last notes:

If you don't like the 120 second respawn timer? Reloging doesn't take that long (about 30-50 seconds, maybe), and you may have to relog anyway on account of glitches.

If you want a game to try that incorporates similar realistic physics and gun handling, try the (albeit singleplayer) game Reciever"."

After playing it for a short while I am ready to give my impressions.
I will present them in a + - list. I will try to avoid crritisizing things that are obviously WIP


First off, most negative reviews seem to be dorf syndrome - people reacting negatively to the difficulty/learning curve rather than actual problems.

+atmosphere is there - two factions fighting in a barren desert for water. There is a lot of empty space between each area and it's quite... comfy
-some clunky controls that are there just for sake of inconveniencing - EG having to unscrew and rescrew cap for the canteen, open/close the lid of a compass. The animations are a bit too slow. While the slow speed of using equipment can be a great gameplay mechanic, I don't think it is a good idea to make it frustrating and annoying to use. There's nothing you can do with a closed compass or a closed canteen. Having an extra closed states serves no function other than a filler. It's like having a scene in a movie which does not evolve the characters or drive the plot forward - just useless filler you're better off cutting.
-/+Lack of generic interaction key - operating taps on water drums requires you to use two keys to close and open it. There's no reason it could not be done with one key. Unless developers are planning to use two interaction keys as part of gameplay
+never before seen control over your firearm - sure it's a bit clunky(mostly since we can't rebind controls yet) but once you get used to it its miles ahead of Receiver.
+lack of UI - this makes game both more immersive and interesting since you have to look at the object to know it's state. EG wether a magazine is full or empty.  I do hope however, that we will see an inventory" where you can see how many items you have left and repack magazines
-loadout screen is a bit basic - could use the ability to configure what goes into each item slot(pouch)
+vast scale of map - despite being large (Project Reality scale) it isn't painful to traverse on foot. Moving to an objective only takes a few minutes and you can use that time to keep an eye on it.

*PRIOR WARNING-THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. IT IS NOT A BASIC SHOOTER LIKE COD, IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR THAT TURN THE OTHER WAY*

Now, onto my review:
My review for this game is very simple. It's not simple at all. This game was not made, at least in my opinion, for the masses. I don't expect this game to be as large as say Planetside, but at the same time I don't expect this to be as small as Red Sabre. This game is a moderate game created with one particular gamer in mind, the simulator. I'm talking the people who take more than a tutorial in game to learn how to operate things to the most realistic fashion. People who play DCS and Train Simulator, people who are trying to live a life they don't currently live or may never live. The problem is that it's hard to sell a simulator on a gaming platform, and that I understand. I don't expect everyone to like this game nor do I expect people to want to learn how to comprehend this game. You'll know exactly whether or not you'll want this game by reading the forums and reviews. Don't give this a shot if you THINK you'll enjoy it, because chances are you won't and you'll get a refund. But if you're someone who wants to take MilSim to a level that isn't quite hit yet (I'm including ARMA) then invest and help develop this outstandingly brave simulator.

Not recommended IF: You are expecting a completed game. Recommended IF: You like the idea of this game, don't mind it being (quite) rough around the edges, and want to support the development of this game.

I am glad I bought it, as I would like to see it developed further. Overall, the controls are clunky- but if you read the guides it's not very difficult. The game is easier for me to play with a steam controller than it is with KB+M.

Pros:
- More depth to reloading and operating your weapons. Reloading is not just a click and wait. Did you save a round in the chamber?
- Graphics options are not bad.
- Customizing your weapon is cool (though somewhat limited)
- Large Map
- Fun multiplayer when there are people to play with
- Recoil Effects and shooting is a blast.
- Going to jail for Team Killing really makes you want to identify your targets correctly and helps deal with trolling.

Cons:
- Map is empty and lacks diversity
- Player movement is very 0 / 1 feeling... clunky.
- Animations need work
- In-Game sounds need work
- Basic tasks are not straight-forward enough. ( ~ + 7 + MMB + hold R + left click + ~ to fill water bottle) In game tutorial would help.
- Bullet ballistics do not seem ... very complex. It hits the reticle pretty much without any adjustment.
- the AI seems VERY dumb. They just stand there, or just stand there and shoot.
- Only two weapons, one for each side.

What I would like to see is more fluid movement, a smaller, more dense map with less bots (or none)... basically CQB designed for ~8-32 players. Also, make the gun float around the screen to require the use of iron sights / scopes... otherwise however you adjust your head --> sights... it always will shoot at the center of the screen.

TLDR: I look forward to seeing how this game develops. Buy if you want to support the development. In it's current state, it's not worth what you pay for it, but it has a lot of potential... and is worth it if the developer puts some more love into it! I am happy with the purchase.
